newsitem.title: UK: Cadbury to use derivatives of gene soy.
newsitem.headline: Cadbury to use derivatives of gene soy.

text.p: Cadbury's, the confectionary arm of Cadbury Schweppes Plc, said on Tuesday it would use derivatives of genetically-modified soyabeans in its products from next year.
A spokesman said the company believed genetically-altered soyabeans were safe and in any case it was impossible to separate them from ordinary beans.
"It has passed the safety regulations in the U.S. and the EU and there is no requirement for labelling. We believe it is safe," the spokesman told Reuters.
Chocolate manufacturers mainly use lecithin, a derivative of soyabeans, as an emulsifier. But its share in a bar of chocolate is tiny and other emulsifiers can be used.

Soyabeans being harvested in the United States for the 1996/97 season have been at the centre of aggressive campaigning by Greenpeace and consumer groups who say a possible risk to human health cannot be ruled out as soya is used in some 30,000 food products.
The beans have been genetically-altered to resist a weed killer in technology developed by U.S. chemical company Monsanto.
Nestle SA, the world's biggest food and beverage company, said it would use genetically-altered soy derivatives in its products, except in Germany where consumer reaction has been most acute.
Nestle's spokesman Francois Perroud said in a telephone interview from Switzerland genetically-altered soya products would be used in Britain as in other countries worldwide.
